title: Gaza Ceasefire Under Strain: Hostage Delays, Renewed Violence, and US Warnings Mark Tense Week
topic: Gaza ceasefire faces severe tests over hostage body returns, renewed conflict, and US warnings.
story:
A fragile ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas, initially brokered by US President Donald Trump last Thursday as part of a 20-point Gaza plan, has faced its most significant challenges this week amid renewed violence and disputes over the return of Israeli hostage bodies.

Escalations began on Monday when Israel launched lethal airstrikes and cut off all aid to Gaza, following a reported Hamas attack that killed two Israeli soldiers, including an officer. Retaliatory Israeli strikes claimed the lives of at least 28 Palestinians. Separately, three people were killed near the ceasefire line on Monday. Hamas officials claim Israel has violated the ceasefire 80 times since it took effect, resulting in the deaths of at least 80 Palestinians.

On Tuesday, the ceasefire's fragility was severely tested. Israel threatened to reduce humanitarian aid into Gaza by half and keep the crucial Rafah border crossing with Egypt closed, accusing Hamas of failing to comply with the deal by delaying the return of deceased Israeli hostages. Hamas, in turn, attributed these delays to difficulties in locating burial sites.

Later on Tuesday evening, Hamas handed over four more bodies of deceased Israeli hostages to the International Committee of the Red Cross, bringing the total number of bodies transferred since the ceasefire began to eight. Four previously returned bodies were identified as Yossi Sharabi, Daniel Peretz, Guy Iluz, and Bipin Joshi. Twenty bodies are still to be accounted for. Following these transfers, Israel reversed its earlier stance, announcing it would allow the Rafah crossing to open and would not cut humanitarian aid.

Diplomatic efforts continue amidst the tensions. Palestinian officials and Hamas representatives have been engaged in further peace negotiations in Cairo, with Egyptian officials undertaking "round-the-clock" contacts to de-escalate the situation. US Vice President JD Vance, during a visit to Israel, expressed "great optimism" for the truce's durability. However, the Emir of Qatar, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani, condemned Israel's "continued violation" of the agreement.

Key figures have publicly addressed the unfolding situation. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, in a Monday speech to the Knesset, reiterated his commitment to disarming Hamas, demilitarizing the Gaza Strip, and ensuring the return of all Israeli hostages. He also spoke of forging additional peace agreements with US President Donald Trump. President Trump himself issued a stern warning, stating Hamas must disarm or "we will disarm them." He further indicated he would consider allowing Netanyahu to resume military action in Gaza, asserting that Israeli forces could return "as soon as I say the word" if Hamas fails to uphold its end of the ceasefire deal, noting he had previously "held them back" from more aggressive action.

Despite the ceasefire, the humanitarian crisis in Gaza remains a grave concern. Aid agencies report that most restrictions on essential supplies persist, throttling the supply of desperately needed assistance, despite initial hopes for a surge of humanitarian aid.
figure: Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani
